properties.Info: A small valley leading up to the mountain of Moel Sych in the Berwyn range of hills

Links.title: River Conwy and valley near Estuary

properties.Info: The mountains technically stretch from South Wales to Snowdonia, but in more modern times has come to refer to the mountains in Mid Wales. They are a wild and often desolate place, but also very beautiful and a popular place for walkers and climbers. Two great rivers, the Wye and the Severn, rise in them. The highest point in the range is 752 metres.

This is the highest peak in the Aran mountain range and the highest British mountain south of Snowdon. It is also nine metres short of being a member of the Welsh 3000ï¿½s (feet). Due to its remoteness it is not as popular as other mountains to visit, but it is a dramatic sight from the air

Links.title: River Conwy and valley near Estuary

properties.Info: The town is home to the annual book fair and has over thirty bookshops, many selling specialist and second-hand books. Even the 12th century castle and its 17th century mansion are used for bookselling

Links.title: River Dee and the Flintshire Bridge

properties.Info: The castle is a good example of one built by the Welsh Princes, as opposed to one built by the English. However, in 1277 shortly after the castle had been completed, and without the approval of Edward 1, it was taken by the English, who then altered parts of it. By the late 14th century the castle was already in a state of poor repair and was finally abandoned

Montgomery is an historic county town in the Welsh Marches, with many fine houses lining the grid plan layout. On the hill is the ruined castle, which was begun in 1223 and formed part of the English defence along the Welsh border. It was attacked several times, but was never taken by Welsh forces. Ironically the town and castle are now in Wales

In 1972 a railway preservation society was formed to re-open the line from Llangollen to Corwen, after it had been axed in the ï¿½Beechingï¿½ cuts. By 1996, after years of hard work by dedicated volunteers, the line had reached Carrog just short of Corwen

The castle we see today was probably built sometime in the late 1260ï¿½s by the local Welsh prince. It was eventually taken by the English then regained by the Welsh before finally being taken back by the English. It must have been a hard castle to take on top of its high hill
This is a spectacular ridge facing west and overlooking Llangollen. It is a very popular place for walkers, as it affords fantastic views over the rolling Welsh landscape

First to be built was the aqueduct in 1801, designed by Thomas Telford to carry the Ellesmere Canal across the valley. The cast iron trough used to carry the water is hidden behind a masonry faï¿½ade. In the 1850ï¿½s the railway viaduct was built, which effectively put the canal slowly out of business

Links.title: St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)

properties.Info: Rhyl is a seaside town, which was very popular in Victorian times. By the 1970ï¿½s with cheap package holidays on offer Rhylï¿½s popularity declined dramatically. New investment programmes have been started to revive the townï¿½s fortunes

Links.title: Bodnant Garden on the River Conway

properties.Info: For many years the Point of Ayr was most famous for coal, with a tunnel extending out under the North Sea. Today it is a popular place to holiday with a broad sandy beach and a lighthouse built in 1776, which was eventually replaced with a lightship

Links.title: River Dee and the Flintshire Bridge
St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)

properties.Info: With the arrival of the railway in the 19th century Prestatyn developed into a holiday resort. ï¿½Sunny Prestatynï¿½ became famous for its beach and promenade entertainers, but like other resorts it has suffered in recent years with holidaymakers preferring to fly to the sun

The estuary is a major wildlife area and one of the most important in Britain. Seals bask on the sandbanks and the patterns left in the sand and mud by the retreating tide looking wonderful from the air

It was Edward I who built the castle we see today as part of his ï¿½Iron Ringï¿½ of castles across North Wales. It survived two Welsh attacks in 1294 and 1400, but by the 16th century it had begun to deteriorate and finally during the Civil War was partly demolished to make it useless as a fortress

The vast Victorian house was begun in 1871 and took five years to build. It had fifty two bedrooms and staff quarters for another 60. It even included a room for just ironing the newspapers so that the print did not come off on peopleï¿½s hands. Today the house stands empty waiting for a new lease of life

The main claim to fame of the pretty town of Llanrwst is that the bridge, Pont Fawr, is said to have been designed by the well known architect Inigo Jones. Certainly the date of construction, 1636, makes it a possibility

properties.Loc: Bodelwyddan Castles and 1st WW trench training area
properties.Info: Between 1830 and the 1850ï¿½s the original castle house was turned into a sort of fantasy castle and was further embellished in the 1880ï¿½s. Part of the grounds were used for trench warfare training during the First World War, and traces of the trench work can still be seen

Links.title: River Dee and the Flintshire Bridge

properties.Loc: St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)
properties.Info: It is often claimed that St Asaphï¿½s is the smallest cathedral in Britain. The earliest parts of the present building date from the 13th century after Edward 1 burnt down the previous one in 1282. But it was in the Tudor Age that the building was finished and then greatly restored during the 19th century
The castle was built in 1282 by the Earl of Lincoln following the conquest of Wales by Edward I. However, it was successfully besieged ten years later in another Welsh revolt by Madog ap Llywelyn

Links.title: St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)

properties.Loc: Bodnant Garden on the River Conway
properties.Info: This large and beautiful garden was begun in 1874 and in a sense has gone on ever since. It is divided into two parts ï¿½ the upper level around the house with Italianate terraces, and the lower level, called the Dell, with a wooded valley full of specimen trees

This was one of the wonders of its age and people travelled from far and wide to see it. Completed in 1805 it is 307 metres long, 38 metres high with a 16 metre span between the 19 pillars. The width is only 3.4 metres, just enough for a barge and towpath

Links.title: Bodelwyddan Castles and 1st WW trench training area

properties.Info: Completed in 1848 the Cefn Viaduct is a fine example of Victorian railway building, and stands close to the Pont-Cysylte aqueduct

properties.Loc: River Dee and the Flintshire Bridge
properties.Info: The River Dee has nearly run its seventy mile course by the time it gets to the canalised section, which was dug in the 18th century to improve navigation. The Flintshire Bridge was opened by the Queen in 1998, and is the largest asymmetric cable-stayed one in Britain

properties.Loc: River Conwy and valley near Estuary
properties.Info: The river flows through a beautiful valley for the last half of its journey to the sea. The Conwy is twenty seven miles long and during spring tides tidal for nearly half of its length. The river is popular for Salmon and Sea Trout fishing

Links.title: Bodelwyddan Castles and 1st WW trench training area

properties.Info: This is a mountainous area on the eastern side of the Snowdonia National Park. Foel-Fras itself is 942 metres high

Situated just to the east of Snowdon Glyder Fach and Tryfan are striking mountains in the National Park. Tryfan is 915 metres and one of the highest mountains in Wales. Both are very popular to climb with Tryfan requiring a good deal of scrambling from the start

The lake stands in the shadow of Tryfan, a mountain where it is said that Sir Bedivere, one of the Knights of the Round Table, is buried. Llyn Ogwen claims an even greater legend as the resting place for King Arthurï¿½s sword Excalibur. True or not the lake is a beautiful place and popular with anglers

We owe it to Thomas Telford, the 18th century engineer, for re-building the A5 road, which goes through to Holyhead and takes you along the southern shore of Llyn Ogwen before dropping down into the impressive Nant Ffancon Valley

Snowdon is the highest mountain in England and Wales at 1085 metres. It has also been described as the busiest mountain in the UK because of the number of people who climb it, as well as the thousands who go up by the steam train. In 2009 a new mountain top station and cafï¿½ replaced a rather ugly older one

The railway is the only public rack and pinion one in the UK and has been in operation for more than a hundred years opening in 1896. The single track has passing loops along the way in order for trains to pass. There a several halts and stations along the route to the final ï¿½Summit Stationï¿½ at 1065 metres.

A magnificent castle built by Edward I as part of his Iron Ring. Caernarfon still retains its fortified town walls, which gave protection to the population. It was at Caernarfon that Edward I, following his conquest of Wales, presented his son with the title ï¿½Prince of Walesï¿½, and set a precedent, which was repeated in 1969 with the investiture of Charles, Prince of Wales

Links.title: River Dee and the Flintshire Bridge
